TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant confessed before the police to committing robbery together with CARDINAL other individuals DATE . The stolen goods were confiscated by the police that DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant left the country on a number of occasions and returned each time .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , who was abroad at the time , was appointed an ex officio lawyer and was charged in absentia with robbery .
CARDINAL . The first hearing of the case was held on DATE in the applicant ’s presence .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE the NORP ORG found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment , suspended for DATE .

CARDINAL . Following an appeal lodged by the applicant ’s co - defendant , in a final judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the lower court ’s judgment including the applicant ’s conviction and sentence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ordered the imposition of a ban on the applicant leaving the country on account of his conviction and pending his rehabilitation . It relied on section CARDINAL ) of the DATE Bulgarian Identity Papers Act .
CARDINAL . The applicant contested the order arguing that he was unable to provide for his family in GPE and that he had employment opportunities in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was refused passage by a border police official while attempting to leave GPE in spite of the imposed prohibition .

CARDINAL . By a final judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the prohibition . The court reasoned that it was within the administrative authority ’s discretion to impose such a ban and that its assessment was not subject to judicial control . At the same time , it held that the law had been complied with in that such restriction could be imposed in cases where a conviction was in place and prior to the rehabilitation of the convicted person and that other factors , such as the impossibility to find employment in GPE , were irrelevant .

CARDINAL . The relevant domestic law and practice concerning travel bans on convicted individuals pending their rehabilitation is set out in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE .
